div.p: Greetings. I received your letter, honorable compater (godfather), and since I assume you have also received mine in the meantime, there is no need for me to add more to them now, nor can I due to various occupations and the imminent departure of the messenger. Kiener writes to Zwingli, your son-in-law, about Tremp's affairs.

He died intestate (without a will), as I hear, and before him, his wife also died similarly; he himself prevented his wife from making a will, and later he was prevented by the heirs, who like harpies (as I remember having written to you several times before) or vultures sat around the half-dead corpse, impatiently waiting for his last breath. They behaved in such a way that I noticed my presence was suspicious to them, and therefore I visited him less frequently in the end. Some friends from the Thurtal have been sent here; three of them are here.

But I do not know what will happen to them. I hear that no one will get anything except the daughter of Batscheler, whom he raised, 100 pounds. There is otherwise much wealth. He had too many dealings; thus, his wealth goes where he will not be much thanked.
They have driven out the old maid so that they can better guard it, even against his own will. What news I have, I have written to my brother; he will share it with you.
I will soon return that Savoyard treaty. Farewell.
Greet your entire household and Mr. Gwalther, to whom I cannot reply now.
Bern, March 4, 1561. Your Haller. To the most distinguished Mr. Heinrich Bullinger, honorable lord and dearest compater. Zurich.
